With [r2269](http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/cgi-bin/redirectLegacyMatforge.py?url=http://matforge.org/fipy/changeset/2269/historical), it is now possible to store values other than `float` in `Variable` objects, but there are some warts to the implementation that should be cleaned up. In general, if a `CellVariable` is initialized with an `int`, unpredictable things can happen if it is later passed to `solve()` or `sweep()`, e.g.::
```python

>>> v = CellVariable(mesh=m, value=1)
:
:
>>> eq.solve(var=v)
```
may produce a different (and undesirable) result from
```python

>>> v = CellVariable(mesh=m, value=1.)
:
:
>>> eq.solve(var=v)
```

[r2270](http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/cgi-bin/redirectLegacyMatforge.py?url=http://matforge.org/fipy/changeset/2270/historical) patches a particularly subtle case that arises from the caching of `typecode` when `--inline` is active (see [r1920](http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/cgi-bin/redirectLegacyMatforge.py?url=http://matforge.org/fipy/changeset/1920/historical)).

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
Currently it is possible to create meshes for rectangular-shaped domains using Grid2D/Grid3D constructors this way:
```
mesh=Grid2D(nx=nx,ny=ny,dx=dx,dy=dy)
```

Please note, that the user specifies resolution along spatial dimensions named `x` and `y` (`nx` and `ny`).

Later, the user has to specify boundary conditions. The sets of faces are given by `mesh.getFacesLeft`, `mesh.getFacesRight`, `mesh.getFacesBottom`, `mesh.getFacesTop`, `mesh.getFacesFront` and `mesh.getFacesBack`.

I like the names of the methods, they are easy to read and natural, but they also bring some confusion: it is not clear which spatial dimenions these sets of faces refer to.

For example, in the reference for Grid3D.getFacesBottom() one may find only this description:
```
Return list of faces on bottom boundary of Grid3D.
```

It does not help to understand whether it means "where z==0" or "where y==0". Even for Grid2D there is already a confusion (I, in fact, had to run some simulations with different boundary conditions to understand what "bottom" and "top" refer to).
I found only one comment in source that explains this issue,
fipy/meshes/numMesh/grid3D.py:
```
X axis runs from left to right.
Y axis runs from bottom to top.
Z axis runs from front to back.
```

I suggest that

* this comment should also be added also to Grid2D

* the reference on all getFacesSide() methods should provide definition of the sides.

* the reference on getFaces, getExteriorFaces and getInteriorFaces should provide definitions of what is exterior and interior faces (is it true that faces == exterior faces + interior faces, and exterior faces are those which have only one neighbour cell?)

* the reference (or manual) should provide an example how to select subsets of faces returned by getExteriorFaces() etc.

If issue mentioned in ticket #101 is implemented, then for getFaces it would be nice to have an interface like this:
`mesh.getFaces(x=Lx)` or `mesh.getFaces(z=0.0)`.

Probably some other idiom which allows to select faces using geometrical condition (e.g. `(x==Lx) or (y==Ly)`) exists, but I did not find an example of such in manual or reference.

 _Imported from trac ticket [#132](http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/cgi-bin/redirectLegacyMatforge.py?url=http://matforge.org/fipy/ticket/132),  created by jetxee+fipy@gmail.com on 06-29-2007 at 09:35, last modified: 04-30-2008 at 18:41_
/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.title: getFacesBottom, getFacesTop etc. lack clear description in the reference

```
nx = 10
ny = 10
dx = 0.1

from fipy.meshes.grid1D import Grid1D
from fipy.variables.cellVariable import CellVariable
from fipy.boundaryConditions.fixedValue import FixedValue
from fipy.terms.explicitDiffusionTerm import ExplicitDiffusionTerm
from fipy.terms.transientTerm import TransientTerm

mesh=Grid1D(nx=nx,dx=dx)
phi=CellVariable(mesh=mesh,value=0)
D=1
phiLeft=1
phiRight=0

dt=0.8*dx**2/(2*D)
t=10.0

phiBCs = ( FixedValue(faces=mesh.getFacesRight(),value=phiRight),
FixedValue(faces=mesh.getFacesLeft(),value=phiLeft) )
phiEq = TransientTerm() == ExplicitDiffusionTerm(coeff=D)
steps=int(t/dt)
for s in range(steps):
```

Tha attached script has a clear memory leak due to the plfp command in Gist2DViewer.
The problem is probably due to the creation of new objects at each time step.
The canvas needs to be wiped in Gist2DViewer before each new call to plfp.
Jon suggested gist.plremove() as a possible fix. This may require us to revert back
to using some of the other commands that worked for grids.

Propose to remove following tests. Numpy asks for the length of
the Variables with `len()` which goes into `__len__`. This raises an
exception in numpy since Variable is not a sequence. I think this
problem lies with numpy expecting the members of the list to
be integers, sequences or floats. Unfortunately, `Variable(0)` is none
of these.

```

>>> numerix.array([Variable(0), Variable(0)])
[[0,]
[0,]]
>>> print Variable(0) + Variable(0)
0
>>> numerix.array([Variable(0) + Variable(0), Variable(0)])

>>> numerix.array([Variable(0), Variable(0) + Variable(0)])
[[0,]
[0,]]

```

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
When the attached script is run, the following error is thrown intermittently

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scripy.py", line 190, in ?
density.setValue(density[:] + densityRelaxation * densityCorrection[:])
  File "/Users/wd15/Documents/python/fipy/trunk/fipy/variables/cellVariable.py", line 146, in setValue
Variable.setValue(self, value, unit = unit, where = where)
  File "/Users/wd15/Documents/python/fipy/trunk/fipy/variables/variable.py", line 597, in setValue
self._markFresh()
  File "/Users/wd15/Documents/python/fipy/trunk/fipy/variables/variable.py", line 692, in _markFresh
self.__markStale()
  File "/Users/wd15/Documents/python/fipy/trunk/fipy/variables/variable.py", line 688, in __markStale
subscriber()._markStale()
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '_markStale'
```

This error can be corrected in the script by either of the following two patches.

Patch 1:

```
196c196
<                                    numerix.dot(density.getGrad(),densityCorrection.getGrad()))).getGrad()[:,dim]
---
>                                    numerix.dot(density.getGrad(),densityCorrection.getGrad()))).getGrad()
198c198
<             velocity[dim].setValue(velocity[dim] - velocityCorrection[:] / ap * mesh.getCellVolumes())
---
>             velocity[dim].setValue(velocity[dim] - velocityCorrection[:,dim] / ap * mesh.getCellVolumes())
```

Patch 2:

```
97a98,103
> velocityCorrection = (classicalPressureDerivative * densityCorrection - temperature * epsilon1 * \
>                       (densityCorrection * density.getFaceGrad().getDivergence() + \
>                        density * densityCorrection.getFaceGrad().getDivergence() - \
>                        numerix.dot(density.getGrad(),densityCorrection.getGrad()))).getGrad()
> 
> 
187,192c193,194
<             velocityCorrection = (classicalPressureDerivative * densityCorrection - temperature * epsilon1 * \
<                                   (densityCorrection * density.getFaceGrad().getDivergence() + \
<                                    density * densityCorrection.getFaceGrad().getDivergence() - \
<                                    numerix.dot(density.getGrad(),densityCorrection.getGrad()))).getGrad()[:,dim]
<             
<             velocity[dim].setValue(velocity[dim] - velocityCorrection[:] / ap * mesh.getCellVolumes())
---
> 
>             velocity[dim].setValue(velocity[dim] - velocityCorrection[:,dim] / ap * mesh.getCellVolumes())

```

The problem can also be solved by putting a gc.collect() inside the sweep loop.
The problem that is occurring in this problem is that new subscribers are being
created during the loop and not being cleared up by garbage collection. That is
why the second patch seems to be working. If the subscriber count is printed for
the density then it can be seen that this varies from loop to loop. When the subscriber count goes from 12 to 13 is when the error is thrown. None of this
explains why getSubscribedVariables() is not removing all the None type
subscribers or why they are reappearing in __markStale()

Mention in the Windows installation instructions that the tests can be run from within the Ipython environment without a full source dist. To run the examples tests

```
  >>> cd examples
  >>> run test.py
```

and for the modules

```
  >>> import fipy
  >>> from fipy.test import _suite
  >>> fipy.tests.testProgram.main(defaultTest='_suite')
```

May be just better to include setup.py as part of the zip.
since the above method throws loads of errors due to
what seemingly is the formatting of ipython. e.g.

  >>> Variable(value = "1 m").getUnit()

gives a "got nothing" error from the test suite since ipython is returning:

   Out[48]: <PhysicalUnit m>

instead of

   <PhysicalUnit m>

May be able to switch a flag in the ipython environment to fix this.

The file examples/levelSet/surfactant/expandingCirlce.py has a bug that becomes apparent as the mesh is refined. This becomes apparent in the error norms for
successfully finer grids. The basic problem is due to all the
surfactant not being passed through in front of the interface when
the distance function changes sign.

The file expandingCircle.py needs to be made into a good demonstration
of the accuracy of the surfactant update scheme as it has been cited
in the superfill book chapter. An updated expandingCircle.py has been
attached.

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
The code below throws a ZeroDivisionError. This is due to the ImplicitSourceTerm, being
a CellTerm, calling getOld() on its coefficient. The coefficient's old value cannot be
evaluated. See code below:

```python
from fipy import Grid1D, CellVariable
mesh=Grid1D(nx=2)

from fipy.variables.cellVariable import CellVariable
phase = CellVariable(mesh=mesh, hasOld=1)
phase.setValue(1)
coeff = (2 / (phase > 0)) * 5

from fipy import TransientTerm, ImplicitSourceTerm
eq = TransientTerm() + ImplicitSourceTerm(coeff)
## coeff.getOld() ## throws a ZeroDivisionError if uncommented (it should do!)

eq.solve(phase) ## throws a ZeroDivisionError error
```

CellTerm should not be calling getOld() for an ImplicitSourceTerm. The remedy may be to
not build all the keys in self.coeffVectors in CellTerm, but only those with nonZero
or nonNone weights.


 _Imported from trac ticket [#98](http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/cgi-bin/redirectLegacyMatforge.py?url=http://matforge.org/fipy/ticket/98),  created by wd15 on 10-13-2006 at 14:36, last modified: 11-22-2008 at 23:31_
/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.title: ZeroDivisionError for CellTerm when calling getOld() on its coefficient

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
boundary conditions should reshape the value argument if it is a cell or face variable. For example if you have a mixed value boundary condition, you should be able to write
```python
FixedFlux(value=(var - var0) * h, face=mesh.getFacesLeft())
```
where `var` is a `CellVariable`. In this case the value will be a
`CellVariable` but it will be made into a `FaceVariable`, then a
`take()` can be done to extract the correct elements in `_buildMatrix()`.

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
`CellVariable` `hasOld()` should set `self.old=self.copy()` if `self.old` is `None` and `hasOld` was not explicitly set to `False` in `__init__()`. This avoids the problem of forgetting to set `hasOld=True` when using `sweep()` and then `sweep()` just iterating forward as if it was a full time step.

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
It appears that the `DiffusionTerm` and `ConvectionTerm` need to be on the same side of the equation. The following code demonstrates the problem:
```python

from fipy import *

mesh = Grid1D(nx=10, dx=1.)
var = CellVariable(mesh=mesh)
convCoeff = VectorFaceVariable(mesh=mesh)
convCoeff[:6]=-1e+6
diffCoeff = FaceVariable(mesh=mesh)
diffCoeff[6:]=1e+3
print convCoeff
print diffCoeff
BCs = (FixedValue(value=1., faces=mesh.getFacesRight()), FixedValue(value=0., faces=mesh.getFacesLeft()))
dTerm = DiffusionTerm(1000)
```
broken
```python
eqn = UpwindConvectionTerm(coeff=convCoeff, diffusionTerm=dTerm) h2. dTerm
```
works
```python
eqn = UpwindConvectionTerm(coeff=convCoeff, diffusionTerm=-dTerm) dTerm
eqn = TransientTerm(1e-10) h2. UpwindConvectionTerm(coeff=-convCoeff, diffusionTerm=dTerm) +  dTerm
eqn = 0 UpwindConvectionTerm(coeff=-convCoeff, diffusionTerm=dTerm) +  dTerm
eqn = 0 == -UpwindConvectionTerm(coeff=convCoeff, diffusionTerm=dTerm) +  dTerm
eqn.solve(var, dt = 1e+10, boundaryConditions=BCs)
print var
```

 _Imported from trac ticket [#82](http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/cgi-bin/redirectLegacyMatforge.py?url=http://matforge.org/fipy/ticket/82),  created by wd15 on 08-06-2006 at 13:48, last modified: 03-30-2007 at 16:38_
/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.title: Some combinations of DiffusionTerm and ConvectionTerm do not work

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
There are places in _buildMatrix where we are recreating variables everytime we call _buildMatrix.
Creating variables is relatively expensive due to the

- shape calculating using the op,
- getUnit() (although it shouldn't be)
- building C strings (for small problems)

I think we are recreating these variables due to our caching issues. It seems that we should be able to
keep the variable object but just explicitly tell it not to cache. For example in diffusionTerm.py we have

>>> coeff = self._getGeomCoeff(mesh)
>>> minusCoeff = -coeff

and then later on we say

>>> del minusCoeff
>>> del coeffs

It seems like for those situations we should be declaring as self.coeff the first time through but then saying
self.coeff.dontCache() after declaration and then there is no need to delete. If we are running
--cache mode on then we probably want to keep self.coeff anyway and not delete it.

The hacked version of epydoc in `utils/epydoc/` produces a line in the master `api.tex` file
```
\usepackage[index,pdftitle={Title},pdfcreator={epydoc 2.1}]{epydoc}
```
and `epydoc.sty` declares
```
\DeclareOption*{\PassOptionsToClass{\CurrentOption}{hyperref}}
```
intending to pass the `pdftitle` and `pdfcreator` options on to `hyperref`. 

This does not work, as those options are declared by `hyperref` using `keyval.sty`. We need to do something similar or come up with some other way to generate these options. This is not an issue for our primary use of `utils/epydoc/` as a way to generate the manuals, since we ignore `api.tex` in that case, but it does mean that the hacked epydoc can't be used on individual files and it will certainly need to be fixed before sending to Ed Loper.

`__pos__` function should work for terms. It specifically didn't work for ExplicitDiffusionTerm. This is not imperative but avoids weird bug. One might write
```
TransientTerm() h2. + ExplicitDiffusionTerm - SourceTerm 
```
That wouldn't work. Would have to be 
```
TrasientTerm() ExplicitDiffusionTerm - SourceTerm
```

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
```
In the interests of making the documentation simpler to read, a great many of &internal& classes were &hidden& by prepending their names with '_'. The problem is that many public classes, e.g. ExponentialConvectionTerm, are derived from private classes, e.g. _ConvectionTerm and _FaceTerm. The private classes provide many methods that are crucial to using the public classes, but these are presently not documented. Either: (i) some epydoc setting needs to be found to cause these methods to be documented in the public classes. (ii) the &hidden& status of these classes needs to be re-evaluated.
```

 _Imported from trac ticket [#49](http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/cgi-bin/redirectLegacyMatforge.py?url=http://matforge.org/fipy/ticket/49),  created by jguyer on 06-27-2005 at 17:19, last modified: 01-11-2007 at 07:03_
/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.title: Documentation is not inherited from &hidden& classes

/issues?state=closed&since=2014-03-20T21.body:
```
FaceTerm and NthOrderDiffusionTerm objects do not work correctly if their coefficients are not either FaceVariables or simple numbers. CellTerm objects require a coefficient that is either a CellVariable or a simple number. Presently, if a CellVariable is supplied to a FaceTerm or a FaceVariable is supplied to a CellTerm, they fail rather cryptically in solve(). They should throw an error on __init__().
```

A FixedValue boundary condition might conceivably have a different form for a DiffusionTerm than for a ConvectionTerm. Where does this get taken care of? Already a problem for PeriodicBoundaryCondition and explicit face terms (VanLeerConvection). Should BoundaryConditions be Terms? They create/modify L and b, but they do so differently for each Term they apply to.

```
Write an efficiency script as part of setup.py to run a number of examples that records run time and memory usage, e.g., $ python setup.py test --efficiency --mesh_size mesh some_mesh _description or $ python setup.py test_efficiency --mesh_size (small, medium, large, massive, humongous, etc, etc) Each script builds smaller or larger meshes depending on the mesh_size descriptor. The medium flag for example will make the script run the small and medium size meshes Ouput should be something like this: Problem Size Elements run_time solver_time memory ======================================== phase small 10000 1234123 2323 4545
```
